Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie is so wonderful! In particular, she did a really terrific job leading a class.

Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  I would have liked to hear more from Kellie and her research areas. Her insights were always interesting in class, but she didn't speak up very often. I would have also appreciated more direction from her or Karen in the beginning of class on S&A style and expectations. I also think it would have been a time saver if Kellie had downloaded and shared all the course readings for everyone, as is typically done in other classes, and if she printed and turned in the S&As for us each week.
Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie was great, super responsive and was a constructive contributor to class discussions as well!
Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie was well organized, very accessible, made valuable contributions to the course, and was very respectful to students' perspectives.

Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie provided great insight in our class. When she facilitated our class discussion, I think that she ran class well but could benefit from continuing to practice leading seminar discussions.

Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  She was helpful, knowledgeable and easily assessible for answering questions over e-mail. More office hours would have been great, especially during the beginning of the course when we were just learning how to do the weekly written assignments.

Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie seemed solid, but the class structure didn't allow us to really take advantage of her as a resource. It would be great to have her more involved somehow in the future.
Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie was very responsive and made herself very available to answer questions. She did a great job explaining concepts and grading.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is one of the very special courses offered at FES. The workload is huge - as much as twice what it is in some easier courses. but it is worth every minute that a student puts in. The material is crucial to an understanding of GHG mitigation. Karen Seto is an amazing instructor, and she pours herself totally into the course. Class is conducted as a seminar, and the discussion is always fascinating, and superbly moderated.

During the initial review of this course earlier in the semester, Karen agreed to cut down the number of readings. I think this was a good move and would suggest limiting the number of readings from the get-go the next time the course is offered- five, dense scientific research papers is more than enough, especially when many of them are quite long.
This course is the best course I took this semester. It was also the most difficult. I highly recommend it to anyone who is willing to work hard and learn a lot.

This is the best course I have taken at F&ES. In addition to being unique in terms of content/focus, there is no other course that provides similar skills building in the area of analytical reading and writing. The writing skills I gained from this class have drastically improved my ability to write persuasively, and I feel much more confident in applying to jobs, grants, and other contexts in which concise, persuasive writing is necessary. In addition, I truly feel an expert on a such for the first time since coming to graduate school. I will be teaching a short course this summer, and I look forward to using the classroom techniques that Karen uses to engage in active discussions. I was surprised every week at how fast three hours passed! I hope that F&ES takes the knowledge of how passionate students are about this subject to increase the number of courses in this area.
This was the best course I have taken at F&ES.
13 - Professor Seto is both very well informed on the subject matter and a great educator. Despite the class sessions being long, she varied the activities and kept us highly engaged.

One of the best courses to take at FES. Karen is an exceptional teacher who cares about students leaving with mastery of the material and the skills necessary to communicate the subject to a wider audience.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Karen is an incredible professor and role model. She clearly knows the topic and cares about her students.

Karen is the best aspect of this course. She's engaged, insightful, prepared, and passionate about her work. She did an exceptional job of encouraging real dialogue in class and I think I learned a ton. It's a shame it's not offered more often or open to more students. I wish she taught other courses.
The quality of the discussion in the classroom and the instruction from Karen Seto.

Prof. Seto's deep, deep expertise in the subject was absolutely invaluable. I also learned a lot from my fellow classmates, I think Prof. Seto did a great job assembling a diverse set of perspectives in the class.

Gained a great level of knowledge of the context of urban areas in climate change and the current discussions around that topic. Vastly improved my writing and assessment skills due to the homework assignments.
Karen's teaching and the full class discussions with a small class size.

The structure of the course and of the assignments were very conducive to learning. The small group breakout sessions were really helpful for going over concepts and learning about how other students perceived the course concepts. It was also a valuable team building exercise and help strengthen our ability to synthesize group perspectives under a tight deadline.
The class discussions were immensely valuable to my understanding of course material, and the students brought unique and interesting perspectives to the class.
Classtime. Discussion was engaging, well structured, and useful. Listening to/learning from Karen Seto was excellent and a highlight of my time at Yale.
Reading list and class discussions/exercises.

We practiced taking scientific knowledge and translating it into actionable policy steps for climate change mitigation in urban areas. We learned both to read, synthesize and write clearly. These are highly transferrable skills.
We have covered climate change and cities from many different angles and improved our abilities of synthesizing and presenting technical information.

Karen's teaching style kept students engaged by mixing up the format of instruction frequently. Very well organized grounding in the material with good breath and depth. I would say that both Karen's instruction and the rigorous grounding in the material were top aspects.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: To be honest, none. This was the best course I have ever taken.

The readings were too heavy in the beginning. I could have used more feedback on my S&A's- I thought they would be totally marked up, but they were actually more often returned to me with a couple underlined phrases and a grade. I needed more instruction on how to improve, and it would have been nice to get them back sooner. I also disliked that they had to be printed and turned in by hand every week.

The quantity of reading at the beginning was a little too much, but Prof. Seto responded to feedback partway through the course and tapered it slightly. I came in expecting to read a lot for sure, but in the beginning getting through ten articles while also learning how to synthesize them well was a touch too much.
I would've liked to get to reading/discussing the policy solutions earlier than we did.

The instructor and TA could provide specific comments and suggestions on assignments. Some of the later classes seemed a little redundant. There could be a stronger emphasis on the social consequences of some of the policies discussed, with perhaps a class session on specific case studies. Overall the course worked extremely well.
Although I think there was a heavy workload for this class, it was necessary to convey the course material and improve our analytical skills.

I think this course needs to be structured so that it can be offered in future semesters. Karen says that she will not offer the course in the future because of the time suck of grading our assignments. However, her comments on our assignments were not lengthy or really meaningful and I think two good TAs would be able to do the same, which would demand less time of Karen. It seems to me that Karen is looking at the course as "all or nothing" when I would rather there be something in the middle so that future students get the honor of learning from her. If she doesn't offer the course in the future, she should not be advertised as a professor at F&ES, because she is a big reason why I and others come here.
More diverse perspectives need to be incorporated into the readings and discussions.

More support in the earlier part of the course would have been helpful as we learned what was expected of us in the writing assignments. For example, a workshop where we gave peer feedback on each other's first drafts would have been helpful in the second week of class.
While we were warned that the course would be reading and writing intensive, would it be possible to design it so that students could learn as much without having this class take over their lives?

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A
Yes. It was great.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course was a great complement to my academic focus on climate change; it's the only course that allowed me to dive into the role of cities in this context.

I came to F&ES to learn about urban planning in the context of climate adaptation and mitigation, and this was a perfect course to take. Not only is the course material incredibly timely and relevant, but the opportunity to learn from one of the leading experts in the field was phenomenal.
This course is critical for my interest in urbanization, land use, climate change solutions, and GHG emissions. It is exactly the field I want to go into.
I am focused on current and possible climate change solutions - addressing this in urban areas is key.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I had heard Karen was a tremendous professor, and I really wanted to deepen my knowledge of urban climate change mitigation.

I heard great reviews from fellow students and I am personally/professionally very interested in climate change mitigation. Getting a much better perspective on the role of urban areas in climate change was really helpful both in my understanding of the broader crisis/solution set and my planning for what to do after graduation.
See answer to question 20.

I heard Karen was an amazing professor and she is! It's also related to my focus area - climate policy - and I did not know much about climate mitigation in cities specifically before taking this class.

To learn about the strategies cities can use to mitigate climate change, and the sociopolitical contexts and consequences of those strategies. I was also interested in improving my writing, which was a strong component of the course.
Topical interest, Great past reviews, Karen Seto.
Interest in climate mitigation.
I had heard a lot about this class. It was a core area of interets for me.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
YES! They exceeded them.
A resounding YES! I feel really qualified to speak on a broad range of urban climate change issues, which was not at all true at the beginning of the semester.
Yes.

Absolutely. I learned a huge amount about climate change mitigation in urban areas while also getting much better at synthesizing literature on the topic (which has already started helping me in other classes as well).
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes
Yes, and surpassed them.
Yes it did. I learned as much as I hoped I would from this course, and have a new perspective on urban systems and climate policies.
Yes. And I had high expectations.
yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, very much. You learn how to read and synthesize the scientific literature quickly and effectively and how to communicate it to different audiences.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was very helpful to draft the first policy memo with a partner.
I would've liked to pick my partner for the first policy memo, but otherwise it was fine.
helps to synthesize the readings for each week.
It helped to learn to write the first policy memo with a partner as we could brainstorm ideas and proofread each other's work as we combined it into a single document.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it if you can. There were 40 applications for 15 spots in the class.

Take this course! It's a lot of work, but you'll gain incredibly valuable skills, learn a lot, and form lasting bonds with your classmates and Karen. This was the best course I have taken in my 19 years of schooling.

Take it! This course was a real high point in my academic career at F&ES. I would strongly suggest that others enroll, but would advise them to make sure they have the time in their schedules to accommodate the heavy work load. It's worth it.

The workload is in some ways greatest in the beginning of the semester as you get used to reading that quantity of journal articles and trying to distill them, but it balances out over the course of the semester as you get better. Still a lot of work, but worth it!

Demand for this course greatly exceeds available slots. You have to be 100% committed to the course to first get in, but second to really get a lot out of the course. This course is highly recommended. Professor Seto has said that she may not be teaching it again in the near future - interested students should reach out to her directly.
Definitely take it!! Allow yourself enough time to do the readings and thoughtfully write the weekly S&A's, it will pay off in the end.

I hope it's offered again, because we need more courses like it with professors that are as actively engaged in student learning. Be prepared to work a lot, but to benefit just as much. Come with specific questions to shape the direction of the discussion.
This is a great course.
It's a lot of work (think of it as taking up the time of two courses) but well worth it if you can get in.
Do it.
This class is great, but the weekly reading and writing take over your life. If you are going to take this class, try to have light workloads in your other classes for the semester.

A course not to be missed if you have the opportunity and are interested in climate change and cities, but be prepared to invest a lot of time in the course - minimum of 10 hours per week and usually more. It's worth the time investment though!
